importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the original crime—killing four members of the Luna family—establishes the timeline of the case and underscores the long duration of the conviction and execution.
The date of Djerf’s execution reflects a significant moment in Arizona’s ongoing death penalty practices and highlights recent legislative and procedural developments.
Executions resumed in 2022 after a hiatus, marking a turning point in Arizona’s capital punishment policy following previous drug-related issues and public scrutiny.
A pause in executions in 2023 due to a Democratic-led review indicates shifting political and moral debates about the death penalty in Arizona.
The conclusion of the review in November 2024 allowed for resumption of executions and signaled a potential return to capital punishment enforcement.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: This period marks the recent revival of executions in Arizona, with a focus on procedural improvements and political tensions over capital punishment.
The pause in executions during this time reflects growing public and political skepticism about the ethics and execution procedures of the death penalty.
A long-standing pattern of criticism and procedural delays in Arizona's lethal injection process, beginning with the 2014 execution, has shaped public trust and policy debates.

keyTakeAways: Richard Kenneth Djerf was executed in Arizona for the 1993 killing of four members of the Luna family, an act of revenge over a claimed theft.
The execution marks Arizona’s second execution of the year and the 39th of 2025, highlighting ongoing use of the death penalty despite past controversies.
Djerf’s execution occurred after a 29-year prison sentence and included procedural difficulties, such as poor vein condition and multiple attempts to insert IV lines.
The state has faced criticism for execution delays and botched procedures, including in the 2014 execution of Joseph Wood, which raised ethical and legal concerns.
The case reflects broader national debates over capital punishment, with five more executions scheduled across the U.S. this year.
The execution of Djerf occurred without the presence of victim families, and the state’s death row now includes 107 prisoners.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a significant and controversial event, Richard Kenneth Djerf, 55, was executed in Phoenix, Arizona, on October 18, 2025, for the 1993 murder of four members of the Luna family—Albert Luna Sr., Patricia Luna, Rochelle Luna, and Damien Luna—after a 29-year prison sentence. The killing was driven by a false belief that another family member, Albert Luna Jr., was responsible for a prior theft. Prosecutors allege Djerf sexually assaulted Rochelle, beat and murdered her father, and fatally shot and tied the mother and son. His execution, the second in Arizona that year and the 39th of 2025, marks the resumption of capital punishment after a 2023 pause due to political and procedural concerns. Arizona faced criticism in the past for execution delays and botched procedures, such as in the 2014 execution of Joseph Wood. The process for Djerf’s execution took about 10 minutes, with difficulty in IV insertion due to poor vein conditions. No family members were present. The state’s death row now includes 107 prisoners, and five more executions are scheduled nationally in 2025, reflecting ongoing national debates about capital punishment.
title: Arizona Executes Man for 1993 Killing of Four Family Members in Phoenix
